The publication date of the article, indicating the latest update on ongoing tensions between Colombia and the US regarding maritime strikes and sovereignty violations.
The date when President Donald Trump made public statements about the latest submarine attack, reinforcing the narrative of US drug interdiction operations.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The six-week period from September to October 2025, during which the US conducted at least six naval strikes in the Caribbean Sea, including the fatal strike on the Colombian boat.

keyTakeAways: Colombian President Gustavo Petro has accused the US of 'murder' following a US strike on a fishing boat in Colombian territorial waters on 15 September 2025, claiming the boat was adrift and had raised a distress signal due to engine failure.
The fisherman, Alejandro Carranza, was reportedly killed during the attack, and he had no ties to drug trafficking, highlighting the controversy over the targeting of civilians.
US President Donald Trump claimed that the latest vessel was a drug-carrying submarine filled with fentanyl and other narcotics, and that it was not an innocent fishing boat.
The US has carried out at least six strikes in the Caribbean Sea in recent weeks, with at least 27 people killed in prior attacks, and the first reported survivor of a strike in the region.
UN human rights experts have labeled the US actions as 'extrajudicial executions', raising international concerns over the legality and ethics of such operations.

The US government has not provided evidence or details about the identities of the vessels or individuals on board, creating a lack of transparency and fueling accusations of violation of sovereignty.

The attacks have intensified US rhetoric against Venezuela, with Trump reportedly authorizing CIA operations and considering attacks on Venezuelan soil, while Maduro has accused the US of attempting to make Venezuela an 'American colony'.
Narco-subs, often homemade and made from fibreglass and plywood, are increasingly used to transport drugs due to their stealth and ability to be sunk after delivery.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Colombian President Gustavo Petro has accused the United States of committing 'murder' after a US naval strike killed fisherman Alejandro Carranza in Colombian territorial waters on 15 September 2025. The boat was reportedly adrift and had raised a distress signal due to engine failure, with no link to drug trafficking. US President Donald Trump defended the attack, claiming the vessel was a drug-carrying submarine loaded with fentanyl, and stated that two survivors would be returned to Ecuador and Colombia. The incident is part of a broader pattern of at least six US strikes in the Caribbean Sea in recent weeks, with UN human rights experts labeling the actions as 'extrajudicial executions'. These strikes have intensified diplomatic tensions with Venezuela, where President Nicolás Maduro accuses the US of attempting to turn the country into an 'American colony'. The US has not provided evidence or details of the vessels or individuals involved, raising concerns over transparency and sovereignty violations.
title: Colombia accuses US of 'murder' after strike on boat
